1.c: Lack of adeqaute transportation along lake road -- smoke and stench from industrial plants.
1.b: Adequate schools -- all utilities.

areaDesc.5: This small area, while spotty, embraces the newer and better section of Cudahy. Several new houses were constructed during 1937 west of Packard. The better and higher income groups of this industrial town reside in this area. The future of Cudahy is not encouraging. Sheridan Park is to the east.

1.c: None.
1.b: All utilities -- good transportation to downtown area, and also along the lake front to the south and out into the country. Schools. South Shore Park to east is a favorable influence.

areaDesc.5: Desirable neighborhood in which to live due to the lake front view - the Archiocese of Milwaukee is to the south and South Shore Park is along the northeast. Prevailing winds from the lake makes this area somewhat more desirable in which to live in summer. Best development along lake. Older section follows the lake. The Archdiocese of Milwuakee prevents growth to the south.

areaDesc.1: This area lies in the crest of a steep bluff and has a wonderful view of the city, Puget Sound and the mountains. People with an income in the high brackets populate this area. The homes are of the larger type and well maintained. There is a good demand for property in this district.

1.c: None outstanding.
1.b: All utilities -- adequate schools -- Menomonee Parkway to the west -- artesian well water -- adequate transportation -- nearby, Blue Mound Country Club and an exclusive grils' college.
1.a: Level with slight rise from North Avenue to Center Street.

n.2: Very few, if any, for rent today.

areaDesc.5: This area, situated in Wauwatose, offers much promise of being one of the better of the newly developed sections due to the suburban influence and the fine park system to the west. Virtually all of the houses herein have been built during the last three or four years, and financed chiefly through FHA loans. Despite the proximity to the cemetery and older section to the east, new houses have been built recently on both sides of 82nd Street. There is a distinct cleavage in the types of property midway between 81st and 82nd Streets in this area. The older section surrounding Wauwatose Cemetery seems to have had no deterring influence upon the eastern portion of this new area. Blue Mound Country Club to the northeast is an advantage; also Mount Mary College, an exclusive grils' school.

1.c: Transportation fair -- development to the west stopped by County Institutions.
1.b: All utilities -- artesian well water -- schools.

areaDesc.5: The northeast corner of the main area was originally the Village of Wauwatosa; Honey Creek Parkway is being developed very nicely and attracting new homes. The east portion of area is substantially better than the west section; industry is to the northwest and northeast and County Institutions to the west. City Park is northeast and there is also park development on south of area. To the east of the eastern section is Sholes Park and the Menomonee River runs along the northern boundary. The area is spotty with considerable new building on the west side. One adverse influence is the location of the mental cases and old people's home of teh County Institutions along north 84th Street.

1.c: Distance from high school facilities.
1.b: Convenience to grade schools, churches, transportation, recreational and trading centers. Presence of all utilities and conveniences. Harmonious population and improvements.
1.a: Fairly level with gradual slope from east to west and a distinct rolling tendency in northern portion.

2.a: Business and professional men, executives, etc.

areaDesc.5: Zoned single-family residential. (Deed restrictions expired last year). Location provides natural protection and pattern of neighborhood is firmly established. This area suffered greatly during the depression and there were a great many foreclosures. This situation has improved greatly in the past three years although there are still a number of acquired properties on the market. The area is one of great charm and appeal. Reed College and the Eastmoreland Golf Links, with its natural lakes, which adjoin the area on the north and west, add greatly to the popularity of the district. The area is accorded a medium green grade. HOLC loans in area approximate 64 for an aggregate of $288,000.

areaDesc.3: Good transportation - trains + trolley - desirable residential area - Restricted development.
areaDesc.4: Much of the territory is undermined and some houses have sagged slightly.
areaDesc.14: Dormont has a very good business section, a post office branch + two branch banks. Brookline also has a branch bank and a shopping center on Brookline Blvd. Greatest danger of mine cave is in lower lying section.

15.1: J. C. Dillon - Property management broker - Freehold Realty Co.

areaDesc.1: This is an old section changing from residential into industrial.  Houses range in age from 20 to 50 years; much rehabilitation is necessary.  Frame construction predominates; one, one and one half and two story homes occupied by laboring class are located here.  Due to its proximity to railroad and railroad yards and heavy industrial area it is rapidly declining.

1.c: Boxed in on three sides wtih factories -- possibility of further industrial encroachment.
1.b: Low taxes -- adequate transportation -- schools -- all utilities.

areaDesc.5: This is the most desirable section in West Milwaukee. It shares with other portions of West Milwaukee the advantage of low taxes inasmuch asindustry practically maintains West Milwaukee. Compared to other parts of the Milwaukee metropolitan area, it is a fair second grade section.

1.c: Foreign element to the north -- railroad to the north and industrial section to the northeast.
1.b: Restrictions as to price -- all utilities -- schools -- adequate transportation.

areaDesc.5: This new area is the best spot in West Allis. The portion between 57th and 60th has built up during the last few years with a substantial type one and one-half and two story houses. Although a good section, it lacks the charm of other good residential sections of the Milwaukee area. Restricted area. The future of West Allis is good.

1.c: Railroad to south and industry east and south.
1.b: All utilities -- adeqaute transportation -- good schools.

areaDesc.5: City Park to the southwest now being developed. The area is situated on a bluff rising from State to Milwaukee Avenue and is not an outstanding area; but spotted throughout with many good homes especially on the east and north. Stone quarry to the southeast. A good "C" area.

1.c: To the south of J. I. Case South Works is Lakeside with salons, night clubs, colored element, etc.
1.b: Good schools - near DeKoven Academy on east. Stephen Bull School is in this area. Churches (Polish) and Racine Street business section to the west.

areaDesc.5: This is a Polish settlement - about 80% of the foreigners are Poles. These Poles are considered of the better or best class in the city. Most of the inhabitants are employed at J. I. Case South Works and Nash Motors, also the LAkeside Malleable Casting Company. Employment at the Case factory has been steady except for strike periods of 2 - 3 months. Nash Motors are idle generally from September to March yearly. South of this area is vacant park land and Racine Sewerage Disposal Plant now under construction. This no considered detrimental.

areaDesc.2: Hilly - sloping both sides from Brownesville Road

5.a: white collar class - clerks - small business men

areaDesc.14: Knoxville is a very stable neighborhood - houses are better than most of the rest of the section but the entire area is very spotty. Many homes need paint and minor repairs. About 55% of the owner occupied homes are mortgaged.

1.c: Outside city.
1.b: None, except adjacency to Racine County Club.

areaDesc.5: One resident, the Janes estate, worth approximately $15,000 and another house of 8 rooms worth $8,0000 are the outstanding homes; otherwise the area is stagnant, very sparsely settled, and with very little future.

1.c: None outstanding.
1.b: Highly protected and restricted -- adequate transportation -- all utilities -- adequate schools.
1.a: Hilly to rolling; several ravines in area.

areaDesc.5: This is Washington Highlands, a highly restricted and exclusive area, slow in developing but substantial in character. Plans and specifications for new building must be approved by the Washington Highlands Building Committee which permits a wide latitude of discrimination in accepting residents into the neighborhood. That small portion of the area south of Milwaukee Avenue, joined on the east and west by "C" sections, is in a deep ravine. High ground along the southern boundary of this area fronting on Milwaukee Avenue forms a natural barrier so that C-17 on the south offers no adverse influence on this area.

1.c: None outstanding.
1.b: All utilities -- homes restricted to $5,000 -- adjacent to Grant Park -- schools -- transportation.

areaDesc.5: Much of this land is held by A. J. Ricker, Joseph Saxler, and E.H. Baetke who do not care to sell. This is the best residential section of South Milwaukee. When the south extension of Memorial Dr. goes through, South Milwaukee will materially benefit and this area is particular. South Milwaukee may develop into a one industry town (Bucyrus-Erie). The future is not any too encouraging. This area was hard hit within the last twelve months by the removal of about 12 executives of the du Pont Co. who recently moved to Wilmington, Del. Under present adverse economic conditions in South Milwaukee there are no persons of like income to occupy houses vacated, and these properties are a drug on the market. The Grobschmidt Subdivision is immediately south of the Holy Sepulchre Cemetery.

1.c: Industry to the south -- children going to school must cross heavy traffic in any direction.
1.b: All utilities -- fair transportation -- schools. Washington Park is to the northeast.

areaDesc.5: That portion of this area south of Juneau Avenue is part of "Pigsville", the colloquial reference to the low river bed residential sections. This portion drops to a lower elevation. There are several apartments along West Martin Drive which follows the bluff. South of Juneau, also west of Washington Park, are a large portion of duplexes. Singles predominate north of Juneau to Washington Park, also north of Vliet east and west of Washington Park. Old clay pits in center of area are now being filled in by garbage and ashes.

areaDesc.1: This area is the better portion of the "Beach Drive #1 District" of West Seattle. Homes range in value from $5000 to $12,000. A very substantial group of home owners with means populate the area. The majority of the homes are modern and in good repair.

1.c: Lack of transportation and sewage system and deed restrictions. All roadways not yet improved.
1.b: Homogeneous population and improvements. Many view locations. A secluded and exclusive residential district of great natural charm. Adequate utilities and conveniences. Schools, churches and trading centers reasonably available for this type of area.
1.a: Northern part of the undulating crest of long hill or hog back having an elevation of from 400 to 500 feet, sloping rather abruptly to north and east, and more gradually to the south and west. Generally wooded.

2.a: Business & professional men, executives and retired; capitalists.

h.3: Difference in size of lots precludes averaging

areaDesc.5: While not covered by zoning or deed restriction, secluded location, land values and defined pattern of district offer protection. Consideration is not given to scattered old homesteads which occupied district prior to present development and which are slowly being replaced by residences which conform to type. Almost all dwellings have parked acreage in connection, some occupying tracts of 15 acres or more. Some of the wealthiest people in Portland reside in this area. The established pattern of area warrant a high green but owing to the fact that less than half of the land is improved it is accorded a medium green grade. HOLC loans in area approximate 10 for an aggregate of $20,000.

1.c: Industry to the east and odors from Jones Island, Sewage Disposal Plant.
1.b: All public utilities -- good transportation, schools, stores, etc.

areaDesc.5: This area is older than adjoining D-13. That portion of the area east of Wentworth Avenue to Lake Michigan is a more desirable residential section than other portions of the area, being removed from industry and on the lake shore. The area around the northwest portion of Conway and South Bay was formerly identified with the bootlegging industry. There are many Italians in this section. East of Lincoln Avenue is the old and dilapidated section.

areaDesc.1: This locality is composed of modern homes in the $5000 to $7500 price class, all in good condition. This is a view property. The residents are white-collar workers and professional people.

1.c: None outstanding.
1.b: All utilities -- adequate schools -- adequate transportation.

m.1: Not a rent area; virtually 100% owner occupied.

areaDesc.5: This is a very picturesque small area in a wooded section developed by Harter, Chairman of the City Planning Commission, who gave special attention to the artistic features of the section. Virtually all of the financing of houses built during the last three years was through FHA Title II loans. Completion of the new Pulaski High School at the intersection of Oklahoma and 27th Milwaukee area, whereby a nearby cemetery seems to have brought no adverse influence. Jackson Park is on the north.

1.c: Heavy traffic on Bluemound Road and Wisconsin Avenue.
1.b: All utilities -- excellent transportation -- schools.

areaDesc.5: This is an outstanding and substantial area, sufficiently to the south of industry as as to be unaffected by it. Quick transportation is provided to downtown areas. Artesian well drinking water is a decided benefit when compared with Milwaukee water. Sholes Park is to the north.

areaDesc.1: This area leads to Lakewood cemetery, one of the largest cemeteries in Minneapolis.  There are very many funerals passing daily, making residential use of property quite depressive.  Monument workers are located in block immediately north of cemetery on Dupont Avenue, also a very old fire barn and a greenhouse.  Dwellings range in age from 10 to 40 years.  Many duplexes, others mostly frame, two story dwellings in need of much rehabilitation.  Values range from $2000 to $9500.

1.c: Heavy traffic on Bluemound Road -- Calvary Cemetery to the west -- industry to the east -- smoke from the St. Paul Railroad Shops.
1.b: All utilities -- close to good schools -- good transportation.

areaDesc.5: This is a substantial area. There is an encroachment of multiple family homes on Bluemound Road and Story Parkway, and there is heavy traffic on the Bluemound Artery. The area is very handy to downtown Milwaukee. It is also close to the industrial "valley" to the southeast. Bluff Park is to the southeast -- also the National Soldiers' Home is on the south. Woodlawn Court is a beautiful district.

1.c: Surrounded by industry -- Calvary Cemetery to the south.
1.b: Modern utilities including city and artesian well water -- good transportation along the Bluemound Road. -- schools.

a.2: There are a few stores, apartments, and multi-family units on Bluemound Road.

areaDesc.5: This area is on the edge of a hill falling away on the north to the river. It is spotted with some good homes on Wisconsin Avenue, along with the customary stores and apartments on Bluemound Road with some large apartments on Wisconsin Avenue. The area has a mixture of apartments, flats, with singles predominating. It is very handy to the downtown business section via Wisconsin Avenue. The Menomonee River is to the north.

areaDesc.1: This is a new area sparsely settled but protected by buildings and racial restrictions. The ground lies well; street improvements are well laid out. People will buy homes in this area with an improvement in business conditions. The homes now being built are of the larger type and well mtaintained.

1.c: None outstanding -- see Item 5 below.
1.b: All utilities -- direct route to the heart of the city on both Wisconsin and Blue Mound Avenue -- restricted to single family houses -- adequate schools -- Honey Creek Parkway to north.
1.a: Level, slightly rolling toward the western boundary.

m.1: No rent houses in 1929 or at present time.

areaDesc.5: This area, embracing Jennings Subdivision west of 76th and Wellauer Subdivision east of 76th, holds its character very well despite the apparently adverse influence of the older area to the south. The developer has made it a policy of buying up distressed property. This was formerly a golf course and when abandoned was turned into an exclusive subdivision. Some speculative building in the price range of $18,000 to $25,000 has been carried on during the past four months. County institutions are to the northwest.

1.c: No sewerage.
1.b: Electricity, gas, good grade schools, transportation to downtown Milwaukee, and own street lighting.

areaDesc.5: This was formerly an old trading post; it is surrounded by a rich farming community -- many Milwaukee people live here. It is only one-half hour's drive by automobile away from Milwaukee with excellent roads. It is close to Whitnall Park on the south, a very fine one. Along Forest Home Avenue to the east there are fine homes with spacious grounds. This is a growing and substantial community with a population of about 1,000. Greendale, a government housing project consisting of 3,410 acres of land and costing more than $9,000,000, is about three miles to the east. D-18 to the southeast is the very old part of Hales Corners and does not adversely affect B-20. It has very few houses, all centering around the business district.

1.c: None outstanding.
1.b: All utilities -- adjacent to Jackson Park -- schools -- transportation.

areaDesc.5: A somewhat spotted neighborhood with a very fine thoroughfare into town, considered the best section on the south side, and an up and coming district. Industry on the north does not affect the area. A rather substantial development of good homes is under way along Forest Home Avenue to Hales Corners.
